description.narrative: Capacity Development for Effective Delivery
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions

The objective of the project is to enhance the capacity of the Country Office as well as national and subnational institutions to design and effectively and effeciently coordinate, implement, monitor and evaluate development plans and programmes.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

title.narrative: Sustainable Development of Protected Area Systems

description.narrative: Sustainable Devt Protected Area System Ethiopia Project

title.narrative: Sustainable Development of the Protected Area System of Ethiopia
Sustainable Development of the Protected Area System of Ethiopia Prodoc
Sustainable Development of Protected Area Systems
Sustainable Development of Protected Area Systems
Sustainable Development of Protected Area Systems
Sustainable Development of Protected Area Systems

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of men above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Number of women above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste

"The Sustainable Development of Protected Area System of Ethiopia project's objective is to strengthen capacity building across the whole protected areas sector of Ethiopia, in order to achieve a sustainable national protected area system. "
populated place
independent political entity
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Working in an enabled environment sustainable management of the system of protected areas that have biodiversity ecosystem and ecological process conservation as a major objective is ensured
Development and Implementation of the system business plan

comment.narrative: No system business plan Trust fund that includes proposal for retention scheme is under formation
System business plan is developed and Different financing options including trust fund contribute to PA management

Business planning has never been exercised in any of the protected areas despite the fact that EWCA has developed a business planning guideline Government and donor funding are the sources of protected area activities The trust fund which would allow retention of income and diversifying the source is one major option on which the development of a system business plan can be based on A regulation to establish the trust fund has been finalized but has not yet been approved by the council of ministers

description.narrative: Improvement in institutional capacity of Ethiopias wildlife institutions

comment.narrative: EWCAs structure is not based on current state of the art of wildlife management
EWCA is restructured and reoriented to current thought of wildlife management

The organizational restructuring study conducted by a government based management institute that took almost a year is now on final stage Draft proposal has been presented by the consultant two times to EWCA management and commented on The company has now submitted the final version which is expected to be endorsed by July 2015

description.narrative: Involvement and contribution of stakeholders including local community in PA management

comment.narrative: There is no formal involvement of stakeholders in PA management
Model planning and monitoring of PA management with stakeholder participation is tested and replicated throughout all PAs

As it has been discussed in the SDPASEs previous reports regarding involvement of communities and other stakeholders in PA management there have been informal comanagement practices in some of them Based on these experiences it has now been declared by a regulation by the council of ministers to designate boundaries of PAs article 5 ecnclosed that all gazetted PAs should establish a committee composed of local government bodies community members and other stakeholders which is charged with duties and responsibilities regarding PA management Accordingly the project has planned to develop standard terms of agreement that will be signed between the PAs and the committee members

description.narrative: Number of endangered species Walia Swaynes Hartebeest Elephant Ethiopian Wolf Grevys zebra

comment.narrative: Environmental conditions are deteriorating Currently there are 300 Elephants in Babile 250 Ethiopian wolves in Bale 1000 Walia in Simien 750 Swaynes Hartebeest and 197 54 Grevy zebra in Alledeghi
Increase in Ethiopian wolf by 10 Elephants by 10 Grevy Zebra by 20 Swaynes Hartebeest by 20 and Walia by 20 in these PAs

The project has limited resources to conduct national wildlife surveys to proof percentage increasesdecreases of the specified animals However as a result of increased awareness raising programs through media and in workshops as well as staff capacity building efforts and material support by the project only few incidents with regards to poaching of elephants and deaths of Ethiopian wolves through diseases have been reported during the year However then following wildlife numbers have been reported by the experts of the respective PAs
Ethiopian Wolf around 500
Elephant in Babile around 300
Grevy Zebra around 350
Swaynes Hartebeest around 850
Walia more than 1000 no new figure

description.narrative: Protected areas mainstreamed across all relevant sectors

41 Successor plan of GTP from 2015 contains strong references to protected areas in the framework of climate change environmental services gender and poverty reduction
Number and strength of Indicators in the next GTP
Increase in government budget

comment.narrative:
9 Indicators are incorporated in the current 20112015 GTP
USD 16 million including infrastructure

Number of indicators in next GTP remains the same but their strength increases
3 million

Draft national GTP II has been developed with some indicators of wildlife but not yet approved
Lack of evidencebased budget requisition has been one of the reasons for EWCA not to get enough investment budget from government This year infrastructural need assessment and total construction budget requirement has been developed for EWCA managed protected areas with the support of the project

description.narrative:
42 The value of PAs is studied and results are propagated
Compiled data on value of PAs

comment.narrative: A case study with old data
Study on value of 5 PAs
Value of protected areas has been studied by a consultant First draft report of the study has been commented on

description.narrative:
43 PAs are mainstreamed in local level planning
Number of sectors with PA component in their plan

comment.narrative: No sector has such plan
Three sectors in each focal area incorporate PAs in their plan

Different sectors and local government bodies are giving due attention to protected areas as a result of awareness raising efforts exerted so far on value of protected areas The following are some of the examples
In Bale and Kafta Shiraro NPs local police and militia participate in patrolling and law enforcement
A nearby local administration unit Woreda has supported construction of a road for Omo National Park
Wolaita Sodo University has supported Chebera Churchura National Park in creating alternative livelihood schemes to community members living around the park to reduce human pressure
Ethiopian road authority has constructed speed breaks on road that pass through Awash National Park
In the reporting period new community benefit schemes have been created for people living around the protected areas In Senkelle the local community has generated more than Birr 5 MillionUSD 250000 from selling of grass More than 500 people have become beneficiary from biogas technology beekeeping and other economic activities with the support of the project and GEF small grant program
Sectoral programs and organizaitons are increasingly contacting EWCA to obtain information on boundaries of PAs during their planning

description.narrative:
Number of sectors around PAs that incorporate wildlife component in their regular work plan
Number of community benefiting schemes and people benefitting from the schemes

comment.narrative:
No organization other than the wildlife sector has such component in its regular work plan
Three number of community benefiting schemes are available in Bale Simien and GuassaMenz and 7000 people have generated about Birr 4 Million in 2004 ETC

The issue of PAs has become one component in regular plans of local govts investors NGOs and sectoral bureaus around the 2 pilot sites
3 more PAs creates community benefiting schemes for 3000 people generating 2 Million Birr end of project

Different sectors and local government bodies are giving due attention to protected areas as a result of awareness raising efforts exerted so far on values of protected areas
In the reporting period new community benefit schemes have been created for people living around the protected areas In Senkelle the local community has generated more than Birr 5 Million from selling of grass More than 500 people have become beneficiary from biogas technology beekeeping and other economic activities with the support of the project and the GEF small grant program

description.narrative: Replication of good practice models across protected area estate catalysed

31 Capacity of PAs strengthened
Increase in management effectiveness of PAs

comment.narrative: METT score
30 increase in Average METT

Compilation of METT scores have been postponed to 2016 due to time constraints However positive changes are expected as a result of the increasing protected area support to enhance effectiveness of their management

description.narrative:
32 SDPASE project focal PA identified and their capacity built
Increase in management effectiveness in SDPASE focal PA Alledeghi

comment.narrative: Alledeghi METT score 48
40 increase in SDPASEfocal PA

The project could not fully excert all of its effort on few protected areas because EWCA has given priority to system level support But using its limited resources the project has managed to
Construct a rain water harvesting structure in Senkelle for the wildlife aimed at reducing the mortality rate of Swaynes Hartebeests because of lack of drinking water and killing incidents while crossing villages looking for water These increases breeding capacity of the wildlife
Construct an outpost in Alledeghi proposed national park to strengthen wildlife protection
Create an access for water supply in Abijata and Alledghi to reduce fuel and time spent to fetch water which could otherwise be used for park management
Create access to electricity for Babile and Alledeghi to enhance office work

description.narrative:
33 Good practices from the whole system compiled and adapted to other PAs
Number of good practices compiled and tested

comment.narrative: Four model sites are selected but best practice only for one Guassa Menz has been compiled
Good practice of the whole system compiled and tested in SDPASE focal PAs and disseminated to other PAs

As discussed so far the project has not totally focused on few PAs However with the support of the project best practices gained from some PAs have been applied on others For instance
The redemarcation procedures used for Quafta Shiraro Aliitash and Simien National Parks has been applied with some modification to redemarcate Senkelle Alledghi Awash and Gerale It has been found effective that we are also following the same procedure for the remaining un demarcated PAs
Best practice from Simien mountains NP on creating environmental friendly livelihood schemes only bee keeping is taken for time being for the local community has been applied in Nechisar and Cheberachurchura NPs

description.narrative:
34 Community conservation area guidelines applied to target areas PFM CHA PA buffer zones
Guidelines available and applied

comment.narrative: No guidelines
Guidelines applied in 2 cases
The draft community conservation area management guideline could not be finalized due to lack of skill in the sector

description.narrative:
Revision and issuance of guidelines for different categories of PAs
Replication of the existing and new good practices gained from model and pilot sites
Number of PAs with multistakeholder coordinationconsultation in management

comment.narrative:
There are guidelines for hunting
Good practices in management planning business planning and scout training have been replicated
None of the PAs have such arrangements

One guideline is revised and 2 new guidelines are issued
The management planning and business planning are further replicated and other two good practices from pilot sites are replicated
5 PAs are being managed by multistake coordination consultation management

Seven wildlife utilization guidelines have been revised and approved
Best practice in creating alternative livelihoods for communties living around the protected area to minimize unsustainable natural resource utilization from Simien Mountains National Park has been replicated to Nechisar and Senkelle Community members who used to collect firewood for sale from these PAs have been supported to start bee keeping poultry sustainable fishing etc as alternative means of living 204 people 174 female have benefited from these schemes

description.narrative: Sustainable financing mechanisms contributing to protected area budget

21 PA Trust fund is functional and received funding and start supporting PAs
Functional trust fund

comment.narrative: The trust fund is in starting stage
Trust fund established and start financing PA management
The trust fund regulation has now been finalized The project is lobbying for its approval by the responsible body

description.narrative:
22 Business and marketing plans for system and PAs developed and implemented
Number PAs with Business Planning
Marketing strategy
Branding of PAs

comment.narrative:
Only one business plan for BMNP business planning guidelines available
No marketing strategy
There is some informal branding

4 number of PAs use business planning
Marketing strategy developed and implementation started
All PAs are branded for promotion

EWCA is exercising branding of its protected areas using own experts In the reporting period branding for two parks Abijata Shalla Lakes and Awash has been proposed though not approved yet The project has planned to hire an external assistant to fasten the process and ensure quality

description.narrative:
23 Income from PAs and wildlife increased tourism hunting others diversification of products
Percentage increase in income
Number and type of promotion

comment.narrative:
ETB 42 Million in 2004 EC
In 2011 Brochure 2 times TV air time 10hrs Bill board 1 Tshirts 5 type poster 1 type Magazine 1 times

15 increase in income
Doubling yearly productionsponsoring each type of promotion

Income from wildlife tourism has increased by 42 from the baseline year The folowing efforts have contributed to achieve this result
The project has facilitated for journalists to attend all wildlife related events and give media coverage More than 10 events such as world wildlife day mountain trail in Abijata Shalla Lakes National Park burning of ivory stockpile a workshop to amend wildlife proclamation and regulations areal survey in Gambella NP higher government officials visit to PAs etc have been broadcasted through TV Radio and news papers
Signs have been erected in Nechisar and Awash National Parks

description.narrative:
Financial Sustainability Score
Increase in investment in lodges

comment.narrative:
System Financial Sustainability Score to be established in 2013
Only three PA Bale Awash Simien have lodges

10 increase in system Financial Sustainability Score
Additional 4 lodges are constructed in Bale Simien Gambella and Nechsar

Two new lodges are under construction in Simien Mountains National Park New lodges in Senkelle Nechisar and Abijata Shalla Lakes NP are under construction One new lodge in Awash NP has become functional The project has supported identification of areas which are ecologically sound for construction of lodges

description.narrative: Systemic capacity for protected area management consolidated

11 Gaps in the legal framework for PA management bridged
Number of Proclamations and Regulations amended
Contradictions in framework made known

comment.narrative:
Existing proclamations and regulations
No write up on contradictions

3 Proclamations are amended and 11 regulations are issued and the issue of 8 regional regulations are supported
Contradictions are identified

Seven federal regulations and eleven regional regulations to gazete protected areas have been issued Two similar regulations and a regulation to establish a trust fund have been drafted
Revision of two federal proclamations Proc No 5412007 and Proc No 5752008 and one federal regulation Regu No 1632008 has been finalized though not issued yet
Seven utilization guidelines have been approved by the responsible minister

description.narrative:
12 Planning system in place and harmonized
GMPs Business Plans
Policy Paper PAsystem
Management Planning Guidelines and system policy paper
Number of management plans developed and implemented

comment.narrative:
Guidelines and system strategic plan not available
2 GMPs are available and 3 are almost finalized Awash Babile and Gambella

Guidelines and system strategic plan available
5 More GMPs are developed and 5 are implemented

Management plan for Bale is under revision with the support of FZS for which SDPASE is providing expertise support TOR to develop management plan for three PAs in 2016 have been drafted by the project
Five year strategic plan 2015 to 2019 for the wildlife sector of Ethiopia including regions has been developed with wider participation of relevant stakeholders with the support of SDPASE

description.narrative:
13 Institutional implementation capacity both federal and regional strengthened
Increase in customer satisfaction
Number of partners and amount of cofinance secured for PA management
Improvement in EWCAs monitoring system

comment.narrative:
Customer satisfaction data are not collected
14 Organizations are working in PA management capacity building with USD 32 Million
Activity level monitoring

System for customer satisfaction data collection is emplaced
50 increase in customer satisfaction end of project
10 increase in number of cofinancers and 25 increase in amount of cofinance
GEFUNDP capacity building and METT score incorporated in EWCAs monitoring system

In order to increase tourist satisfaction during the reporting period the project has supported government efforts to improve tourist facilities mainly road maintenance in Nechisar National Park and Senkelle Swaynes Hartebeest Sanctuary In addition existing government owned lodges in Awash and Bale have been transferred to private investors A training on tourism and tourist handling has been provided to tourism experts of EWCA
The project has developed an improved monitoring guideline which has incorporated METT and other relevant monitoring tools in Amharic official language of Ethiopia Will be functional once EWCA has endorsed it
Donors funding for wildlife management has increased by more than the target percentage greater than 50 increase The major donors are
A German based donor KFW 20 Million Euro for Simien Bale and Alledghi
Another German based donor GIZ 15 Million Euro for Nechisar Awash and EWCA
IGAD for Gambella NP management 6 Million Euro
AWF for Simien NP 15 Million Dollar
FZS in Bale Guassa Menz Simien 35 Million Euro

description.narrative:
14 Gaps are prioritized and both federal and regional authorities are supported to create new PAs to fill the existing gap in the PA system
Number of new PAs created to fill the gap in the existing PA system

comment.narrative: Gaps in the existing PA system have been identified

Gaps are prioritized
Two new PAs are created in the identified gaps

A wildlife potential area near to Gerale National Park has been identified and demarcated A wildlife corridor has been established to connect it with former park to be administered under one management Boundary of Alledeghi Wildlife Reserve now proposed park has been extended to include additional forest and wildlife potential areas
Boundary of two wildlife potential areas of Benishangul Gumuz Regional State Bejimiz and Maocomo which were under study have been fully demarcated in this reporting period

description.narrative:
15 Capacity of PAs staff developed for effective PA management
Staff skills in the system

comment.narrative: Scouts trainings some professional level training and experience sharing are taking place
The scouts training is conducted in EWCAs training institute partnership is developed

A partnership agreement has been reached on training of scouts with the military training academy in Awash Arba until EWCA is able to construct its own training center A first round training has been provided to 80 scouts drawn from federal and regional PAs
Training of trainers has been arranged for 11 senior scouts in the South Africa Wildlife College They also had a chance to gain practical experiences from Kruger National Park After returning back to Ethiopia they have trained many scouts in their respective PAs and in the training program mentioned above
Short term training on SMART a software based wildlife management tool has been provided to staff of three protected areas
The project has supported 12 postgraduate level EWCA staff students

description.narrative:
Number of best practices consolidated for better PA management
Increase in METT score and Capacity Development Score Card

comment.narrative:
Best practices from APF and FZS on scouts training and management plan have been replicated
System METT score is 50 Capacity Development Score Card not yet applied

4 Best practices Community conservation multistakeholder PA management management planning business planning are consolidated and applied throughout the PA system
40 increase in system METT score Capacity Development Score Card shows 15increase over baseline established in 2013

Multi stakeholder management is one of the best practices which has been tested in some protected areas though informally and based on willingness of the protected areas This has now been declared by a regulation for seven protected areas which makes multi stakeholder management a must to implement
Two community conservation areas have been established in Gambella and Afar Regional States and one more is under study in Ethiopia Somali Regional State with the support of the project However they have not yet become functional due to remoteness of the areas which leads to lack of interest by hunting companies and tourists which again leads to the communities being unable to generate any income But with the current infrastructural development and increase in donors interest the community conservation areas will have a chance to be operational
There is definitely an increase in METT and Capacity Development Score Card scores with the current improvement in PA management Compilation of the actual results is planned for April 2016

Midterm project evaluation Mainstreaming Agro biodiversity

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste

The Global Environment Facility Mainstreaming Agro-biodiversity project objective is to mainstream the four selected crops (Coffee, enset, tef and durum wheat) in to the agricultural system of Ethiopia
populated place
Energy - policy, planning and administration

To provide farming communities with incentives policies capacity markets and knowledge to mainstream conservation of agrobiodiversity including crop wild relatives into the farming systems of Ethiopia
3 agrobiodiversity policies revised to mainstream agrobiodiversity conservation and institutional arrangement for their implementation strengthened

comment.narrative: Currently agrobiodiversity conservation is catered for in some policies and the IBC has the responsibility at national level for its conservation There are policy contradictions and several key policies trade agriculture forestry still do not recognize agrobiodiversity Institutional arrangement especially mandates at the Woreda and Kebele levels still unclear and have weak capacities

At least five policies evaluated for their effectiveness in agrobiodiversity conservation and recommendations for gap filling made by the end of the project Institutional mandates for agroBD conservation clarified at all levels and Woreda and Kebbele governments in 4 pilot sites have capacity for mainstreaming agroBD conservation and governance to enforce policy and legislation provisions on AgroBD conservation

At its final execution period the project has engaged in implementation of the policy evaluation recommendations The policy evaluation articulated the existing policy gaps in the agrobiodiversity conservation and highlighted the need for the establishment of regional biodiversity conservation centers to closely support local communities instead of only the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute working at the Federal level Accordingly nine regional centers at Awassa Metu Goba Shashemene Fiche Mekelle Bahir Dar Harar and Assossa are established and strengthened by the project

description.narrative: 500ha established by end of the project

comment.narrative: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings but no consolidated deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives
At least 300ha of on farmin situ conservation sites established by project midterm and 500ha established by end of the project

The coverage of the land for two cereal crops tef and durum wheat was very from season to season since the farmers are using crop rotation approach to reduce soil fertility loss dissemination of disease insect and so on Accordingly 11867 and 663ha were covered by Tef and durum wheat respectively The area coverage of Forest coffee alone covers 167021ha Therefore the achievement of the project was more than 500ha of land covered by the on farm conservation of farmers varieties of the intended four crops

description.narrative: Markets for agroBD friendly products increased by at least 50 through expansion of value chains and national and international markets for agrobiodiversity

comment.narrative: Currently there is one international agreement on tef less than 5 of coffee being sold as speciality coffee very limited trade on durum wheat or enset
At least three value chains with clear national and international markets established by midproject and five value chains established by end of project

During the reporting period the project was strongly worked on strengthening of the market linkage created between five forest Coffee producing and marketing farmers associations in Yayu and Oromia Coffee exporting farmers union This support given on the strengthening of market linkage to the farmers cooperatives reduced the middlemen and increased the benefit of the beneficiary communities In 2014 the farmers cooperatives supplied 746qt of forest coffee to the International market through Oromia coffee exporting union At Minjarshenkora project site two farmers associations supplied 650qt Tef for consumers cooperative found in Adama Town and 163qt for kesem union Due to the effort of the project the MoU between G7 sack factory and farmers associations has been renewed in 2014 According to the renwed MoU Enset producing conserving and marketing farmers association in Angacha supplied 400kg fiber of Enset and earn better income This all efforts of the project practically increased the capital of the farmers cooperative association and change the livelihood of the beneficiary communities at grassroots level

description.narrative: Reduced or avoided deforestation and forest degradation and improved forest restoration through Payment of Ecosystem Services as conservation incentives

comment.narrative: Awareness of the potential for developing a PES project is very high in the country and some effort is being put to identify specific areas and design projects aimed at the UNREDD initiative However no PES project has been submitted to the CDM yet

At least one PES project on carbon sequestration with a target of 274 M tCO2e ER initiated through REDD by project midterm and an integrated forest managementgovernance structure to ensure continued provision of ecosystem services in place by end of project

The project has aggressively engaged in awareness creation and reforestation efforts in Yayu site Tthe project raised and distributed 648433 indigenous forest tree seedlings to the communities which support the reforestation program Furthermore the project has also initiated the PES study to implement the payment incentives for conservation of biodiversity resources

description.narrative: Crop Wild Relatives are conserved in insitu gene banks set side areas that continue to provide breeding ground for agrobiodiversity
500ha established by end of the project

comment.narrative: In situ conservation happening in many isolated farms holdings but no consolidated deliberately set aside area being managed specifically to maintain wild relatives

At least one Project Design Document PDD carbon sequestration target of 274 M tCO2e ER as a result of better management and protection of the coffee forest completed and placed on the voluntary carbon market by midterm and initial financial benefits accrued by end of project

Strategic Guideline in Integrated Natural Resources Management to increase adaptive capacity of Farmers Varieties to Climate change in Enset Forest coffee Tef and Durum wheat growing Woredas was developed in collaboration with the MoA Natural Resources Mnagement Directorate CRGE unit Validation workshop and training also conducted in presence of relevant stakeholders Currently 200 copies of the document was published and distributed to the project site and other stockholders The English version of the document has been translated to local languages Amharic and Afan Oromo and distrusted to the implementers in hard and soft copies Furthermore the project has also initiated the PES study to implement the payment incentives for conservation of biodiversity resources

description.narrative: Effectiveness of institutions in management of in situ gene banks

comment.narrative: Degradation of in situ gene banks continue unabated since the national and regional institutions charged with the management of in situ gene banks lack effective management strategies

At least 4 capacity building programs are developed and implemented by midterm to ensure 50 of the institutions charged with responsibility for managing the insitu gene banks in 4 sites are effective by end of project

Assessment of the capacity gaps of the farmers associationcooperatives was conducted by consultant Based on the consultants capacity need assessment results trainings were organized on basic accounting cooperative management value chain development for 39 participants 35 male 4 female on operation of multipurpose thresher for 20 participants 2 female 18 male Materials Enset processing tools farm tools office equipment stationery etc were provided to the farmers cooperativesassociations found at four project sites In collaboration with the Ethiopian Institute of Agriculture EIAR participatory plant breeding approaches also continuously supported by the project Furthermore 20 accessions of durum wheat and 12 accession of tef has been retrieved from the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute EBI gene bank and evaluated at the Framers Training Centers FTC continuously in order to comeup with the conclusion of the comparative advantage of the farmers varieties over the improved one Farmers were actively participated on the evaluation of those accessions performance Due to those supports rendered to farmers cooperativesassociations the request for membership of the farmers cooperativesassociations highly increasing from time to time This is one of the practical changes observed due to the wellorganized intervention project at four woredas

description.narrative: Enabling policy and institutional framework for in situ conservation of agrobiodiversity
A strengthened national institutional framework for agrobiodiversity

comment.narrative: A national institutional framework for agrobiodiversity conservation exists but it is dysfunctional
A well articulated national institutional framework for agrobiodiversity conservation agreed upon by midterm and implemented by end of project

As per the five sectors institutional frame work mandates analysis recommendations currently a wellarticulated national institutional framework has been developed and the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute EBI has formulated from the then Institute of Biodiversity Conservation IBC Since the previous one was mainly focused on conservation while the current has made including researches and conservation

description.narrative: An effective ME for assessing conservation status of agrobiodiversity at community level

comment.narrative: Conservation status of FVs and CWR is weak and their contribution to local food security is not well documented

Agriculture programs in the 4 project sites adopt a participatory ME system for assessing the conservation status of FV and CWR by midterm and the contribution of CWR and FV to local food security assessed by end of project

Needs were assessed to identify the capacity gaps of Farmers Cooperatives associations on ME Based on the capacity gaps identified trainings were organized at four project sites for project staffs woreda experts and leaders of farmers cooperativesassociations on monitoring and evaluation for 188 participants 72 females The impacts of the capacity building activities offered so far also conducted at four sites and documented for future use The impact assessment results of the four project site indicated that the capacity building activities implemented so far were really addressing the capacity gaps of the beneficiary communities as well as the local Institution and also facilitate the mainstreaming of the agrobiodiversity conservation principles in to different sectors at all level in the selected project sites

description.narrative: Local institutions have farmer variety bylaws and regulations in 4 pilot areas

comment.narrative: There are currently no farmer variety policies in pilot areas

At least 3 local government authorities assisted to develop capacity and accountability to enforce policies sectoral guidelines and spatial plans in support of agrobiodiversity increased in 5 pilot areas by end of project

The project has developed the capacities of the Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute EBI and the Ethiopian Agriculture Institute of Research EAIR at the federal level Moreover capacities of four local governments at Gimbicu Minjar Shenkora Angacha and Yayu woredas have been developed As a result EBI has supported the establishment of nine regional biodiversity centers EAIR has engaged in participatory plant breeding on the four farmers varieties to improve productivity of Farmers Variety crops All the four local governments have endorsed the local bylaws as official working documents This project best practice is being replicated in the project implementation nearby woredas and kebeles

description.narrative: Ministries of agriculture forestry trade and industry with policies catering agrobiodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Currently Agrobiodiversity friendly policies are scattered and inadequate
At least 3 Agrobiodiversity principles mainstreamed into local and national agricultural trade and industry policies and programs

The project has supported to mainstream key agrobiodiversity principles into relevant government sectors such as Agriculture Trade Industry and Tourism by i Increasing knowledge and understanding of agrobiodiversity as an essential resource for sustainable development and wellbeing In this relation all the four project sites local governments have mainstreamed this principles in all relevant sector offices ii The project has contributed for global significance and influences research and policy agendas on agrobiodiversity For example farmers varieties of Durum Wheat gene pool is attracted researchers for controlling wheat rust which is highly devastating the improved varieties of wheat both nationally and globally Moreover research on drought resistance and early maturing varieties is being done by the local researchers on Teff and Durum Wheat in collaboration with the project iii The project has put its effort in mainstreaming the importance of wild species in agricultural landscapes food sources and key ecosystem functions through the restoration and conservation of Teff Durum Wheat and Yayu Forest Coffee iv One of the greatest achievements of the project is its ability to involve farmers and local communities respects and strengthens their indigenous knowledge through the development and endorsement of four local bylaws v The Ethiopian Biodiversity Institute is highly engaged in advocating the conservation of agrobiodiversity and access and benefit sharing at global fora in collaboration with the project

description.narrative: National extension programme promote farmer varieties and land races

comment.narrative: The National extension service has a strong bias to promote HYVs at the expense of traditional farmer varieties
At least 40 of the farmers in the 4 pilot areas provided with skills and knowledge to increase farm productivity and food security by 30 using agrobiodiversity friendly practices

In collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture MoA and Ethiopian Institute of Agricultural Research EIAR the project has been finalized the development of an extension package for four targeted crops Durum Wheat Tef Enset and Forest Coffee 400 copies 100 for each package has been published and distributed to the project sites and relevant institutions ToT training also given for 100 experts came from Zone Woreda and kebel Development Agents level By the coordination of each project site officers the experts acquired the ToT training has providing continues practical trainings for all beneficiaries farmers on the extension packages This improved the skill and knowledge of the farmers and increase productivity of the crops as well as surly contributed to the efforts to the food security Based on the interest of the local experts development agents DAs who are technically supporting farmers at grass root level the project is developing training manuals for the intended four crops in collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture The training manuals will be smutted sooners and trainings will be given for the experts This will be technically support the extension packages found under implementation

description.narrative: Markets for agrobiodiversity friendly products promote farmer uptake of agrobiodiversity conservation imperatives
Awareness of the importance of Agrobiodiversityfriendly products in promoting conservation and communities welfare in Ethiopia raised at local national and international level

comment.narrative: There is limited awareness on importance of Ethiopias agro biodiversity and even more limited awareness of the role this agrobiodiversity plays in local economic development and food security and limited awareness of the options and potential that exist to use specialized products to promote both local welfare economies and conservation Agrobiodiversity friendly products are available but they have not absorbed the available market share

At least 10 international marketing campaigns trade fairs online to establish Ethiopia as an international source of agroBD friendly products held by midterm and production of agrobiodiversity products to satisfy the markets increased by 50 by end of project

Different marketing companies have been done to promote the four intended crops to the world Four billboards and light box one for each crops prepared and displayed at the Bole international Airport since 2014 up to 2016 Three national and international exhibitions and bazar in Addis Ababa Mekelle and Awassa have been conducted and increased the visibility of the four crops nationally and globally One international promotion has been also done at Doha during CoP18 in 2012 The project has also used different international celebrations such as the International Biodiversity day to communicate its achievements globally Furthermore documentary film was produced on the four crops and transmitted on the Ethiopian National Television Additionally two hours interview on importance and use of the four crops also done by the Bisrat FM radio and transmitted

description.narrative: Business and financial capacity in place to produce agroBD friendly products and services in 5 pilot sites

comment.narrative: There are limited credit opportunities for SMEs involved in agrobiodiversity friendly businesses

At least 60 of micro and SM enterprises engaged in AgroBD friendly businesses and services assisted to access credit through partnerships and capacity building of financial institutions by end of project

About 75 of the producers cooperativesassociations have access to credit services Yayu forest coffee producers linked to Sorena Geba Union Minjarshenkora and Tef producer farmers cooperatives linked to Kesam union The credit facilities has supported both associations to improve and increase their products

description.narrative: Increased and stable income from certified and noncertified products grown in agroBD friendly areas shade coffee farms and coffee forest in 4 pilot sites

comment.narrative: The current income levels from agrobiodiversity friendly products are far below the available market opportunities

At least 2 different international crop certification systems established for shade coffee from coffee forest established by midterm project and production increased by 50 while allowing 60 of the coffee farmers in the site to sell products at a premium by end of project

Since the project is working on Yayu forest coffee international certificate has been given by Rain Forest Alliance As the result of the certification producers are able to supply their products to international market such as UK and Germany Furthermore branding for Minjarshenkora farmers varieties of Tef is being finalized in collaboration with Debra Birhan University

description.narrative: International and national demand for five agroBD friendly products increased

comment.narrative: Though there is a demand for agrobiodiversity products such as honey there are more opportunities that can be tapped to increase this demand

At least 4 marketing programs identified differentiated and certified for products from 4 pilot areas eg shade wild and low caffeine coffee durum wheat ensette teff noug by midterm and non certified agroBD products grown in shade coffee farms and coffee forests developed and implemented through a supply chain approach by end of project

Four marketing strategies has been developed and implemented for the four crops Accordingly four market linkages have been identified and implemented through supply chain iTeff producers re linked to Kesem Uniun and Mama Fresh Enjera exporting company ii Enset producers are linked to G7 Sack factory iii Durum Wheat producers are being linked to Akaki Food processing Factory ivYayu Forest Coffee has been certified by Rain Forest Alliance and linked to Oromiya Coffee exporter However the project is supporting the Yayu Forest Coffee producers to form their own union for accessing international market directly

description.narrative: Production processing and marketing of agrobiodiversity friendly products improved in 4 pilot areas through the formation of cooperatives with strong organizational and operational capacities

comment.narrative: There are many local level producer societies but there are major gaps in capacity and in particular they are not differentiated by function production processing marketing they have very limited operational and organizational capacities and fail to link farmers to markets and credits adequately

At least 50 of local level producer societies for specific crops such as shade and low caffeine coffee durum wheat teff ensette in 4 sites promoted as a mechanism of incentives for adoption by linking farmers to markets and credit

The project providing support for 24 farmers associationscooperatives at four project sites which accommodate 76953 members of which 36443 or 47 are females Two metal silo grain storage with the capacity of 10qt for each also bought and handover to Gimbichu site farmers Cooperatives one for each Cooperative Intensive Capacity building trainings were offered to the beneficiary communities on cooperative management and auditing natural resource conservation operation of threshers and others Three market sheds constructed at Gimbichu Minjarshenkora and Anagacha sites were handover to the beneficiary communities and functioning well

description.narrative: Verification and monitoring compliance of certification

comment.narrative: The available certification process needs to be monitored for compliance
At least one protocol to verify and monitor compliance of certification developed by midproject and used effectively by end of project

One Protocol to verify and monitor compliance of Yayu forest coffee certification has been made with Rain Forest Alliance during 2013 Yearly audit was performed and certified that the forest coffee producers were in line with the standards of Sustainable Agriculture Network SAN

title.narrative: UN Flagship Joint Programme on Gender

description.narrative: Joint Program on Gender Equality and Women empowerment

title.narrative: 00061111_JOINT PROGRAMME ON GENDER EQUALITY AND WOMENÂS EMPOWERMENT 00077285
Gender UN Flagship July 2015- June 2016 AWP

description.narrative: Joint Program on Gender Equal.
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

title.narrative: Promoting Autonomus Adaptation at Community Level

description.narrative: Promoting Autonomous Adaptation at community level.

title.narrative: Terminal Evaluation of the UNDP/GEF Project Promoting autonomous adaptation at the community level in Ethiopia
Promoting Autonomus Adaptation at Community Level
Promoting Autonomus Adaptation at Community Level
Promoting Autonomus Adaptation at Community Level
Promoting Autonomus Adaptation at Community Level

description.narrative: Strengthened capacities of government and producer institutions to design, develop and deliver key services and Mainstreaming & operationalization of Disaster Risk Management policy.
populated place

To support local communities and administrations at the lowest level of government to design and implement adaptation actions aimed at reducing vulnerability and building resilience especially in those communities that are particularly vulnerable in Ethiopia
Capacity perception index disaggregated by Gender

comment.narrative: Average CCA capacity scorecard rating of 126 across men and women
CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 3 in target Woredas for both men and women

Since the inception of the project implementation the project has been providing different capacity building trainings to enhance institutional capacity at lowest administrative levels mainly at the 4 Woredas and the 8 Kebeles Mesebo Mesret kebeles in Enderta woreda Selga 23 Kushmengel kebeles Asossa woreda Desta Abijata Kemo Gerbi kebeles in Adami Tulu Jido Kombolcha woreda and PukongPimoli kebeles in Gambela Woreda on how to engage in multistakeholder dialogue assess situation create a mandate and vision formulate policy and strategy budget management and implementation as well as monitoring and evaluation Based on this support task team members have been able to design and provide mentoring support to beneficiary community members at the Kebele level in integrating and implementing new CC adaptation techniques and technologies Furthermore beneficiary farmers have gained practical knowledge on participatory planning methods In so doing capacity in properly designing and implementing CC adaptation measures that would reduce vulnerability and build the resilience of local communities to climate change in the PAA pilot Kebeles and in Addis Ababa has improved In general the institutional capacity is improved for a total of 333 88 F245 M woreda task team membersDA agents Woreda task teams from the baseline 126 to 285 score

description.narrative: Access to technologies and practices that improve the range and efficiency of adaptation options improved
of farmers adopting adaptation technologies by technology type disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Farmers 83 maleheaded 17 femaleheaded currently constrained by limited access to and knowledge of adaptation techniques and practices

By the end of the project 5000 subsistence farmers 83 maleheaded 17 femaleheaded have been trained in and tested climate change resilience building techniques and practices of which 35 of both male and female headed farming households have adopted them permanently

In order to improve farmers access to technologies and practices that have adaptation value the project has provided material inputs as well as technical backstopping for beneficiary farmers and for communal actions undertaken for the purpose of environmental rehabilitation of forests or pasturelands catchment management Thus in this reporting period in all project sites
Climate resilient conservation agriculture and crop diversification practices with the use of drought resistant crop varieties implemented Small scale irrigation to grow market demanding fruits and vegetable crops through using rainwater harvesting technologies low cost drip irrigation systems human powered semi rotary water pumps and small to medium sized solar generated water pumps were implemented improved bee keeping technologies and practices for honey and wax production that could improve the productivity and quality of the produce were supported by provision of modern beehives and accessories livestock production mainly goat and sheep production and fattening programme were implemented Development and use of household biogas energy and also production and use of energy efficient stoves were undertaken Environmental and natural resources management through area closure construction of physical soil conservation measures forest tree planting and other similar practices were undertaken
In order to enable farmers and woreda and kebele officials test the prioritized adaptation measures and technologies practical trainings were provided and an experience sharing field demonstrations were organized by the project to a total of 832 399 F 433 M farmers 40 Developments Agents DAs and 44 woreda Task Team members The trainings focused mainly on different CC adaptation technologies including Climate resilient agricultural crop and vegetable production practices Modern and environmentally friendly animal husbandry mainly goat and sheep husbandry and fattening practices modern apicultural practices including small scale irrigation using rain water harvesting techniques shallow well drilling and application of solar pumps and by applying drip irrigation techniques river diversion techniques rehabilitation of degraded ecosystems production and use of energy efficient stoves and use of house holds level biogas energy production and use Following the trainings a total of 4479 2547 male which is 5094 of the target and 1932 female which is 3864 of the target farmers have been implementing above mentioned CC adaptation technologies and actions on their farm plots as an integrated set of adaptation actions on a total of 1200 hectares of land across all sites

description.narrative: Capacity for communitybased climate change adaptation improved
of targeted population covered by innovative insurance mechanisms disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Informal coping strategies are in use in target areas no formal financial risk reducinginsurance approaches yet in place due to lack of meteorological and hazard information in target areas
By the end of the project at least 25 of the men and 25 of the women in the target communities are using innovative mechanisms to insure against the inherent uncertainty of climate change

In order to facilitate the access to climate information which is considered as a constraining factor in reducing vulnerability to the perceived seasonal unpredictability of weather in all the PAA project sites including in Addis Ababa different activities have been performed in this reporting period Support was provided to the National Meteorological Agency NMA to present its available downscaled weather forecast information which could be used for seasonal projections andor longer term climate related projections for risk planning to target Woreda level planners and beneficiary farmers in a way that they can find it useful and gather feedback in a way that improves their own forecasting In order to create awareness and sufficient understanding to Woreda planners DAs and Kebele level officials on downscaled weather data and on how to interpret this data to climate information and adjust their interventions and disaster risk management plans different training sessions were organized by the project to a total of 1128 487F 641M participants from across the project sites Due to the these trainings Woreda and local level awareness about the issue has increased substantially and about 3896 female and 5128 male target beneficiary communities have started using climate data effectively in their decision making processes Thus in general the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300 from the baseline production level across all pilot sites This shows that there has been an increased production by 2875 than when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period Due to this increase in productivity beneficiary farmers income has increased and substantially supported their livelihood

description.narrative: Institutional capacities for coordinated climateresilient planning and investment strengthened

Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimise exposure to climate vulnerability
Capacity perception index disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative:
Capacity for climaterelated analysis and forward planning is limited at subnational level with an average CCA capacity score of 126 across the 5 functional areas of
Multistakeholder dialogue
Situation analysis vision casting and mandate
Policy and strategy formulation
Budget Manage and Implement
Monitoring and Evaluation

By end of Project 4 Woreda and 1 Regional task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated areabased planning approach
Average CCA capacity score in the 4 Woreda and 1 Regional level is 3 for both men and women

As followup practice from year 2014 the project continued providing training and mentoring support to all the 4 pilot rural Woredas and the 8 Kebele pilot sites as well as in Addis Ababa city government Accordingly in this reporting period training and mentoring support was provided to 264 79 F 185 M Woreda level task team members including planning experts local level government representatives and local community members The trainings have focused on how to Engage in multistakeholder dialogue Assess a situation and create a vision and mandate Formulate implementation policy and strategy Budget manage and implement the planned intervention and Monitor and evaluate progress and feed back into the implementation management After the trainings those who participated in the trainings have used the knowledge to undertake climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated areabased planning approach in their respective Woredas the Woreda Task teams used the skills and knowledge they acquired from the training and undertook climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated areabased planning approach in their respective Woredas Apart from training support Simple pictorialbased information sheets on climate change its causes and effects designed for local community consumption was prepared and have been distributed to local level decision makers planners and extension agents in order to facilitate easy access to climate change related information Capacity building support was also provided to 54 8 F 46 Male in the 4 rural Woreda and to 15 1 F 14 M task team members in Addis Ababa project task team members to prepare areabased climate vulnerability profiles and climate risk analyses using GIS tools as part of the learning by doing approach for the development of the integrated plans After the training task team members have been able to undertake vulnerability assessment and produce local level vulnerability maps and documents for their respective localities All in all it could be said that the institutional capacity score has increased from the baseline score of 126 to 285

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Total number of plans and programmes that are informed by multi-hazard national and sub-national disaster and climate risk assessments
number of plans and programmes that are informed by risk assessments that differentiate impact on men and women

Capacity of key sectors strengthened for accessing and make use of climate information and early warning. Enhance capacity of National Meteorological Agency (NMA) and Hydrology and Water Quality Department.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Ethiopia

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard
2 Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydrometeorological phenomena There are no Standard Operating Procedures SOP for alert communication by NMA to DRMFSS
Current score 83
2 Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure
Current budget low

1 Capacity assessment scorecard score of 139
2 Domestic target financing is 100M Birr per year

40 AWS have been procured One upper air radio sonde equipment has also been procured and is ready for installation A meteorological mobile calibration unit and equipment have been procured and they are already functional Automatic hydrological gauge telemetry equipment has been identified and is ready to procure
Capacity building training sessions for instrument technicians forecasters and support staffs as well as awarenesscreation events for local communities have been held in various parts of the country particularly for all NMA meteorological Branch Directorates staff and meteorological observers

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydrometeorological and environmental information for early warnings and longterm development plans

1 Percentage of population with access to improved climate information and flood and drought warnings disaggregated by gender
2 Development frameworks eg GTP that integrate climate information in their formulation
3 Sectorspecific EW products and strategies that integrate climate risks

comment.narrative:
1 Use of hydrometeorological and environmental information for making early warnings is currently low for both women and men
Women 6 million
Men 8 million
2 Currently no development frameworks incorporate climate change information
3 Limited number of tailormade and sectorspecific meteorological products Limited publicprivate partnerships and pay for services contracts

1 Percentage increase in the population who has access to improved EWSCI 50 increase for women and 50 increase for men
Women 9 million
Men 12 million
2 At least 2 of the PRSP policy briefs incorporate analyses of risk maps andor climate change projections influencing longterm planning proposals
3 Development of at least one tailored climate product and presentation of a market research plan on how to implement mobile phone based agricultural advisories both supporting targeted weatherclimate service delivery

This part of the project will be executed after all the equipment is installed and capacity building sessions are held for experts and at the community level The execution of activities is planned to start in 2016

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of NMA and HWQD to monitor extreme weather and climate change

1 Percentage of national coverage of the weatherclimate and hydrological monitoring infrastructure
2 Frequency and timeliness of climaterelated data availability

comment.narrative:
1 Percentage of national coverage of the weatherclimate and hydrological monitoring network at the beginning of the project
Meteorological stations 1000 manual 70 automatic
Hydrological stations 489 manual 4 with telemetry
2 Frequency of data transmission and collection monthly

1 Increase in 24 national coverage to take steps in achieving NMAs optimal monitoring arrangements as defined in feasibility studies
Meteorological stations 1240 manual stations 110 automatic
Hydrological stations 439 manual 64 with telemetry
2 Frequency of data transmission and collection daily

With the exception of spare parts required to rehabilitate 200 conventional stations most of meteorological equipment was ready for installation However the installation of the equipment and instruments was delayed as a result of difficulties to undertake civil works during the rainy season
